description.narrative: Conservation of globally important biodiversity and associated land and forest resources of Western Tian Shan mountain forest ecosystems to support sustainable livelihoods.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. Trend in population levels of globally significant fauna (Red List, ecosystem indicator or keystone species) in Jalal-Abad province: - Snow leopard (Panthera uncia) - Ibex (Capra sibirica) - Golden eagle (Aquila chrysaetos) - Tian Shan white clawed bear (Ursus arctos isabellinus) 2. Status of globally significant flora in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts: - Semenov’s fir (Abies Semenovii) - Juniper (Juniperus sp.) - Relict spruce (Picea schrenkiana) 3. Area of degraded pastureland in four target A/As in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts - Cholpon-Ata - Kyzyl-Ozgorush - Kok-Irim - Atai

comment.narrative: Negative trend over the past 25 years of individuals that are present at least sometime during the year in Jalal-Abad province. Number of individuals and annual rate of change: - Snow leopard (Panthera uncia): 49; <0% - Ibex (Capra sibirica): 4116; <3% - Golden eagle (Aquila chrysaetos): 31;<1% - Tian Shan white clawed bear (Ursus arctos isabellinus): 197; <4%

Targets Out I: 1. METT scorecard; Alatai SNP (new PA) - 50, Kan-Achuu SNP (new PA) - 50. 2. HCVF management approach has legal basis, and relevant regulations are produced 3. Implementation is initiated (defined as incorporation of HCVF management practices in approved FMPs) in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts. 4/6 on GEF TT scale: “Step 4: The regulations are under implementation” 4. 1000 hectares patrolled per week in 2021 (baseline * four times the number of anti-poaching ranger team patrols for each location. Assessed as the minimum coverage necessary to ensure effective management, regulatory monitoring, and deterrence of illegal activities); 5. E-PA sustem inplemented in PAs of Western TianShan
Targets Out II:
1. 2,979,548 tons CO2 equivalent avoided in Western Tien-Shan by 2021 2. e-Pasture Management System implemented by 4 PMCs in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts by 2021 3. - Women: <11,702 - Men: <12,237 - Total: <23,939 - Index: <100% of total population are affected by land degradation in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts (with a population number index value fixed set at 100 for 2016 (in case of total population increases or decreases)) 4. Income of women 10% increase, men 10% increase from micro-finance/grant program for individuals participating in the program.
Targets Out III:

For Indicator 5 (namely the area of the Jalal-Abad province for which project results will indirectly improve biodiversity, forest, and land management measures), the EoP was agreed as 944,317 ha across the two target districts. Specific areas indirectly influenced by project results cannot be reported and quantified at this stage. The Project has provided extensive support to improve biodiversity, forest, and land management, all of which are expected to impact the targeted areas positively. However, the planned improved management plan for the area was supposed to introduce novel concepts in Kyrgyzstan. These include complex concepts such as HCVF with special management and use regimes, buffer zones for forest enterprises, and migration corridors for wildlife between PAs. The introduction of these zones requires agreements between land and forest users as well as the development of the relevant regulations so that they can be implemented. The development of management plans is an area of work on which the Project is currently falling behind, partly due to the pandemic and internal government restructuring. The project expects that the regulations will be adopted next year, at which point the process of developing plans for improved conservation management can commence. Given the current project closure date of March 2022, this work will not be completed before closure unless the Project is extended. However, related to this Indicator, some indirect indicators showing positive changes in biodiversity conservation. For example, it confirmed the establishment of the new habitat for the Gray Varane lizard and the presence of rare animals listed in the Red Book, such as Pallas cat. By EoP, 18,307 people from the Toktogul District communities (8,979 women and 9,328 men), as well as 5,632 people from the Toguz-Toro District (2,723 women and 2,909 men), were supposed to have derived indirect livelihood benefits from project results (Indicator 6). The vast majority of households keep livestock, and therefore the sustainable pasture management is key to the economic well-being of the local population. Through support provided to the development of pasture management plans and their implementation, the Project is expecting to indirectly benefit nearly all residents of the pilot area, i.e., 20,166 people in the Toktogul District, Cholpon-Ata and Kyzyl-Ozgorush villages (9,879 women and 10,287 men) and 5,836 people from the villages of Kok-Irim and Atay in the Toguz-Toro District (2864 women and 2,972 men). Further, through the grants given to the pasture committees, an additional 3,080 people benefitted directly or indirectly, with some 46% (1,520 people) of these being women beneficiaries. Therefore, progress towards achieving this Indicator is satisfactory. More precise calculations will be provided by EoP as stipulated in the Results Framework. Overall, the Project reports mixed progress across the six objective-level indicators, with some clear areas of weaknesses and uneven results. Some results cannot yet be fully measured or assessed. Nevertheless, considerable support has been provided so far, and notable results achieved. Many are related to delivering foundational work needed to underpin the novel and complex biodiversity and management concepts being introduced in Kyrgyzstan for the first time. This includes such ambitious concepts and approaches as the Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT), High Conservation Value Forest, Sustainable Forest Management, Sustainable Land Management, Joint Forest Management, new management tools for State National Parks and a National Strategy on Snow Leopard Conservation. As was also noted in the MTR, the implementation of these concepts implies the need to develop numerous capacities, including at the institutional and individual levels. Some evident shortcomings are related to sustainable forest management, the introduction of the HCVF concept, development of the management plans, and support to the communities through the low-value grants. Although grant proposals have been obtained and approved, the COVID-19 pandemic postponed the full implementation of the grant component for some time. In addition, local restrictions on conducting any meetings restricted Project travels to the pilot areas. Nevertheless, the Project adaptively managed and decided to purchase equipment for the approved project proposals to continue project activities. The COVID-19 pandemic and the political instability are both force majeure events, sitting outside of the Projects area of control; but it must be recognised that they have had a negative effect on the Project over the past 16 months, which should have been a prime time to realise many of the planned results.

Targets Out I: 1. METT scorecard; Alatai SNP (new PA) - 50, Kan-Achuu SNP (new PA) - 50. 2. HCVF management approach has legal basis, and relevant regulations are produced 3. Implementation is initiated (defined as incorporation of HCVF management practices in approved FMPs) in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts. 4/6 on GEF TT scale: “Step 4: The regulations are under implementation” 4. 1000 hectares patrolled per week in 2021 (baseline * four times the number of anti-poaching ranger team patrols for each location. Assessed as the minimum coverage necessary to ensure effective management, regulatory monitoring, and deterrence of illegal activities)
Targets Out II 1. >40,000 ha of sustainably managed forest in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts by 2021 2. 4,886 ha (500 ha reforestation/afforestation, 4,500 ha supported for natural regeneration) by 2021 3. 2,979,548 tons CO2 equivalent avoided in Western Tien-Shan by 2021 4. e-Pasture Management System implemented by 4 PMCs in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts by 2021 5. - Women: <11,702 - Men: <12,237 - Total: <23,939 - Index: <100% of total population are affected by land degradation in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro districts (with a population number index value fixed set at 100 for 2016 (in case of total population increases or decreases)) 6. Income of women 10% increase, men 10% increase from micro-finance/grant program for individuals participating in the program
Targets Out III: 1.Annual number of seizures: - Snow leopard: <Baseline (at least one seizure assisted by specially trained dogs) - Snow leopard prey: <Baseline (at least one seizure assisted by specially trained dogs) - Other illegal wildlife: <Baseline (at least one seizure by specially trained dogs) - Number of arrests = >baseline - >50% of arrests result in prosecutions 2. International agreement between Kyrgyzstan and at least one bordering country under implementation regarding at least one of the below issues: - Cooperation on law enforcement at border points regarding illegal wildlife trade - Illegal hunting by border guards - Data sharing on snow leopard monitoring 3. Publishing of annual estimates with a 60% confidence level (the average confidence level among other snow leopard range states in GSLEP population estimate)

Overall, the project is on track towards achieving its targets and objectives and with some indicators successfully achieved by now. The project has fully met its targets set for 2020, except for the construction of ranger houses and administrative buildings that were postponed due to the delayed inventory works by state partners related to the documentations on land transformation etc. As preliminarily confirmed by the MTR, the project is well aligned with national strategies and programs as well as with the UNDP and GEF-6 focal areas strategies and has direct response to national priorities. The implementation adheres to the project strategy reflected in the project document. The project secured good progress across its objective level indicators and the overall “Satisfactory” rating is granted, which is in line with the MTR assessment report. Upon RTA’s 2019 PIR recommendations, the project team have been closely working with the SEAPF to avoid potential issues and regularly and timely convened Project Board meetings to discuss and solve problems preventing the project from full speed implementation. Also, MTR management response matrix was finalized and presented to the members of the Project Board, translated version also sent to the partners and shared with the RTA. In March 2020 the Project also was selected as part of the management audit according to the UNDP rules. Project passed management audit successfully and audit report is available for public. Also in December project passed spot check of RBEC Audit for GEF funded projects. METT scores are also showing us the effectiveness of their work. In General, the increase in estimates is due to project interventions in the PAs, such as zoning, equipping with appropriate field and other equipment, repairing and building infrastructure works, supporting the preparation of management plans, and micro-grant support to the local communities.
Out I: - Snow leopard (Panthera uncia): 34; - Ibex (Capra sibirica): 4656; - Golden eagle (Aquila chrysaetos): 72; - Tian Shan white clawed bear (Ursus arctos isabellinus): 261
Semenov’s fir (Abies Semenovii) – 4,930.5 Ha Juniper (Juniperus sp.) - 9,204.6 Ha -Relict spruce (Picea schrenkiana) – 4,322.2 Ha (1) 162,188 ha under SFM in Toktogul and Toguz-Toro leskhozes
(2) 9223 ha of restored degraded forests and support of natural generation of forest. Two forestries updated plans and included biodiversity conservation activities to their plans.
(3) SLM in 119,899 ha of pasturelands
(4) 286,099 ha of PAs and additional territory of lake Kara Suu is 1663 Ha, in total 287762 Ha with improved biodiversity, forest and land management (Achieved, 100% of EoP)
- Alatai SNP (new PA): 23 - Kan-Achuu SNP (new PA): 21 - Sary-Chelek SBR: 59 - Padysh-Ata SNR: 46 - Besh Aral SNR: 47 - Saimaluu-Tash SNP: 40 - Dashman SNR: 44 (additionally included as requested by the National Partners as it is located in the Western Tian Shan landscape).
Jointly with the WWF Kyrgyzstan and the Department of Biodiversity Conservation and PAs, the project supported the development of the METT assessment guide. The methodology was approved by the order of the SAEPF on May 22, 2018, No. 01-9/148 which has successfully been used in all PAs.
Out II: The project provided fencing materials and transportation services to support and promote natural regeneration on 8,923 ha, and new plantings of about 300 ha. Also, preparatory works are in process for planting of about 100 ha. Project has fully achieved the target on the Natural regeneration of forests with extra 4000 ha on top of required 5000 ha indicator.
- Alatai SNP (new PA): 23 - Kan-Achuu SNP (new PA): 21 - Sary-Chelek SBR: 59 - Padysh-Ata SNR: 46 - Besh Aral SNR: 47 - Saimaluu-Tash SNP: 40 - Dashman SNR: 44 (additionally included as requested by the National Partners as it is located in the Western Tian Shan landscape).
Jointly with the WWF Kyrgyzstan and the Department of Biodiversity Conservation and PAs, the project supported the development of the METT assessment guide. The methodology was approved by the order of the SAEPF on May 22, 2018, No. 01-9/148 which has successfully been used in all PAs. The project is in process of developing a joint action plan with the Department of the Forestry on legislation, identification and inventory of HVCF in the Kyrgyz Republic as well as including it into the Forest Code which will be revised in 2020 by a World Bank project in the forestry sector.
Toktogul District, people of Cholpon-Ata and Kyzyl-Ozgorush villages total – 20,166 - 9,879 women - 10,287 men
Toguz-Toro District, people of Kok-Irim and Atai villages total - 5836 - 2,864 women - 2,972 men Using FAO methodology for 2020 the project estimated avoided lifetime indirect GHG emissions of 979,548 tons CO2 equivalent for already reforested areas of 9,217 ha by the Project.
Out III: During this reporting period two cases were reported officially on spotting Snow Leopards by local communities. Health condition of the species was very weak (vision problems and etc.) and representatives of the SAEPF decided to keep them in the rehabilitation centers. There were no other illegal cases reported during this time.
Construction of an open-air cage (for 4 dogs) for the canine service at the Manas International airport is completed with the Project’s support. This will contribute to improvement of the control of illegal wildlife trafficking and improve the cooperation between their involved parties. Also, as a follow up to the CITES meeting, the work on development of Guides for identification of flora and fauna species under CITES is underway. The Guides will be used by customs and border services of the Kyrgyz Republic at the border points of the country and will include printed materials, as well as a mobile application. The Project supports the upgrade of the E-PA management system that will evolve into a single effective tool for management of protected areas. Also, E-PA system will contribute to decrease illegal wildlife trade and trafficking. E-PA system will serve a good platform and tool to monitor and coordinate activities among all responsible institutions such as customs, academia and hunting department of the State Agency on Environment and Forestry. Stakeholders commended the idea to integrate the snow leopard database and the user database in the E-PA information system. Following the discussion at the Khodjand meeting, it was agreed to proceed with development of the final draft MOU, subsequently shared with Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan for agreement. Upon receiving positive feedbacks and general agreement, it is now planned to sign the MOU by four countries (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan) in nearest months. In the Kyrgyzstan we faced some difficulties with the MoU signing at the MFA level, hopefully will resolve all issues and we could sign the MoU within the 2020.
A draft Memorandum of Cooperation on the Conservation of the Snow Leopard under endorsement by the Kyrgyz Government. As for the other countries, as we know we are waiting official approval from Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan.
One of the main achievements is that under the Snow leopard symbol, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic initiated the resolution of the United Nations General Assembly “Nature knows no borders related to the biodiversity conservation including the snow leopard. This will attract more attention to the Project results and aim at supporting the idea of the ecosystem-based management approach at a very high level.
Snow Leopard monitoring database is being developed in partnership with the stakeholders: Biodiversity Conservation and Protected Areas Department of the SAEPF, Panthera, Snow Leopard Trust, NABU and others. In February 2020 in Bishkek, the Project jointly with the GSLEP Secretariat supported a meeting on snow leopard monitoring methodology where all partners jointly developed and agreed on mapping of activities. This will allow the national partners to closer monitor and coordinate activities related to snow leopard monitoring and keeping all data in a single place. The project supports development and adaptation of the PAWS methodology for the Kyrgyz Republic and implementation was postponed due limited access to the regions following the COVID19 outbreak. The project plans to get the methodology endorsed officially and disseminate it to other neighboring countries and share project’s experience and country in general.
